Over 4000 different species of beetles occur in Britain. Their huge diversity in form, behaviour and ecology make them a daunting group for those attempting beetle identification for the first time. To help overcome these barriers for the non-specialist, complex terminology, obscure characters and the need for expensive equipment has been avoided. Ecological notes are included, and the extensive bibliography will direct the reader to species identification if required.
Title: A key to the families of British Coleoptera (beetles) and Strepsiptera

Description: This AIDGAP key should enable anybody to identify adult flies to their family. After approval from academic referees, an earlier draft was subjected to extensive user-testing before the author produced this revised version. An introduction details the characteristics of Diptera so that they may be recognised from other orders of insects:- the key itself leads to the correct family: and a short list of references is appended to guide the investigator's further enquiries.
Keywords: FSC Field Studies (1981) 513-533 AIDGAP true flies
Title: A Key To The Families Of British Diptera

Description: This key is developed from one used on various courses at the Marine Biology Station, Menai Bridge and at Dale Fort Field Centre. This was based on the excellent key in Knight and Parke's Manx Algae (1931), which was modified by the inclusion of genera not found on the Isle of Man and by the addition of a key to the Cyanophyceae. The key has been further modified in the light of experience gained during these courses and expanded to include all the genera in Parke's Check List (1953) and the later amendments (Parke 1956, -57, -59), apart from a few minor exceptions and with the major change that the classification of Drouet and Daily (I956) has been adopted for the non-ﬁlamentous Cyanophyceae.
Title: A Key To The Genera Of The British Seaweeds

Description: A family of weevils with only ten British species, one of them only found in domestic situations and now very rare due to improvements in food hygiene. The illustrated key should allow their separation with reasonable confidence.
Title: Key for the identification of British Anthribidae

Description: Two species of this family are found in Britain, with the larvae feeding in rolled-up leaves of various species of trees.
Title: Key for the identification of British Attelabidae

Description: A key to the two British species is found below. Both are associated with fungi on dry deciduous wood.
Keywords: Biphyllidae False Skin Beetles Polyphaga Arthropoda
Title: Key for the identification of British Biphyllidae

Description: There are only five species of this family of wood-boring beetles occurring in Britain.
Keywords: Bostrichidae Arthropoda auger beetles false powderpost beetles Coleoptera
Title: Key for the identification of British Bostrichidae

Description: A small family in the British fauna, containing species variously classified in the past. The latest checklist has five species in three genera (Teredus, Oxylaemus and Anommatus) and five species.
Keywords: Polyphaga cocoon-forming beetles dry bark beetles Insecta Coleoptera
Title: Key for the identification of British Bothrideridae

Description: The British species of Buprestidae are very few and are mostly restricted to the SE of Britain. They belong to two subfamilies and a total of six genera:
Subfamily Buprestinae
Genus Anthaxia
Genus Melanophila
Subfamily Agrilinae
Genus Agrilus
Genus Aphanisticus
Genus Coraebus
Genus Trachys
Keywords: Buprestidae jewel beetles flatheaded borers Coleoptera
Title: Key for the identification of British Buprestidae

Description: 13 species in 7 genera occur in Britain according to Duff's checklist (2012). Identification to genus and most species should be possible with the key.
Title: Key for the identification of British Byrrhidae

Description: A family containing just two species in Britain, one of which is common and widespread through Britain. The key separates the two species of Byturus.
Keywords: Byturidae Fruitworms Polyphaga Platydascillinae Coleoptera Insecta
Title: Key for the identification of British Byturidae

Description: This AIDGAP identification guide should enable non-specialists to identity the 57 species of centipede found on the island of Britain, including 7 species known only from greenhouses. It includes dichotomous and tabular keys backed up by concise confirmatory notes. Centipedes are some of the commonest larger arthropods found in our greenhouses, sheds, gardens, waste ground, woodland, moorland and coastal habitats, but the standard key (Eason, 1964) is now out of date and out of print. This new key includes the additional ten species discovered during the last 40 years.
Title: Key to the identification of British centipedes

Description: According to Duff's checklist of British Coleoptera there are 67 species of Cerambycidae (longhorn beetles) which are either native or introduced with viable populations in the wild. These are classified in 6 subfamilies
Subfamily Prioninae (1 genus, 1 species)
Subfamily Lepturinae (18 genera, 25 species)
Subfamily Spondylidinae (3 genera, 5 species)
Subfamily Cerambycinae (16 genera, 19 species)
Subfamily Lamiinae (11 genera, 17 species)
Title: Key for the identification of British Cerambycidae

Description: There are five British species of this family listed in the latest checklist, from two genera. The genera are very different from one another and are placed in separate subfamilies. Genus Anommatus was placed within this family by earlier authors but has now been moved to family Bothrideridae.
Title: Key for the identification of British Cerylonidae

Description: There are 22 species from 7 genera listed in the latest British checklist. 15 of these belong to genus Cis.
Keywords: Ciidae minute tree-fungus beetles Insecta Coleoptera
Title: Key for the identification of British Ciidae

Description: A small family in the British fauna, comprising ten species in two genera, genus Calyptomerus and Clambus. The key should help in the determination of the species
Title: Key for the identification of British Clambidae

Description: There are 15 species of this family on the British list but several of these have not been recorded for over 100 years and so are presumed extinct. The species are rarely encountered although a few are reasonably frequent.
Title: Key for the identification of British Cleridae

Description: Some of the species of ladybirds are very common in Britain and easily recognised. There are a number of keys available that identify the common species by colour patterns alone and these should be referred to for beginners.
Title: Key for the identification of the British Coccinellidae

Description: This is a small family of twelve species of mostly wood-boring beetles. Some workers are proposing that this family is combined with the members of Cerylonidae, Salpingidae and Bothrideridae to form family Zopheridae.
Keywords: Colydiidae wood-boring beetles Cerylonidae, Salpingidae and Bothrideridae
Title: Key for the identification of British Colydiidae

Description: A family with only two species in Britain, the more common Pediacus dermestoides and the more local Pediacus depressus.
Title: Key for the identification of British Cucujidae

Description: The current checklist has 9 species in 4 genera from two subfamilies in Britain. The key should enable identification to species for the British fauna.
Keywords: Dasytidae Soft-winged flower beetles Melyridae Aplocnemus impressus
Title: Key for the identification of British Dasytidae

Description: The current checklist has 40 species in this family on the British list from six subfamilies and thirteen genera. They are associated with dry animal or vegetable material, which means some species are pests. A number of species on the British list are only found indoors and some are only known from a few records. Most species are dealt with by Peacock (1993), Handbooks for the Identification of British Insects, Volume 5 part 3.
Keywords: Dermestidae Coleoptera skin beetles khapra beetles Arthropoda
Title: Key for the identification of British Dermestidae

Description: Four species are known from Britain from this family of weevils. One is a very rare species of rotting wood known from Windsor Forest and Windsor Great Park and the other three are cosmopolitan pests of stored cereals. Further information about the species can be found in Morris, (2002) True Weevils (Part I) Handbooks for the Identification of British Insects 5 (17b) p30-33.
Title: Key for the identification of British Dryophthoridae

Description: Friday (1988) stated that the separation of these species depends on the form of the genitalia
Title: Key for the identification of British Dryopidae

Description: The Dytiscidae are a group of water beetles with a good number of species in Britain. They are characterised by long thread-like antennae and include quite a few large species.
Title: Key for the identification of British Dytiscidae

Description: 'The 12 species of Elmidae found in Britain are classified in 8 genera. They are comparatively rarely collected water beetles. The key below should enable you to have a go at identifying them.'
Title: Key for the identification of British Elmidae

Description: The 12 species of Elmidae found in Britain are classified in 8 genera. They are comparatively rarely collected water beetles.
Title: Key for the identification of British Elmidae

Description: A small family in Britain with nine species from five genera.
Title: Key for the identification of British Endomychidae

Description: The 2012 edition of the Checklist of Beetles of the British Isles lists eight species from four genera. Cryptophilus integer has recently been found in the London area and was formerly placed in a separate family (Languriidae). It is now included in the Erotylidae in subfamily Cryptophilinae while the other species are in subfamily Erotylinae.
Keywords: fungus beetles Dacninae, Encaustinae, Erotylinae, Megalodacninae, and Tritominae
Title: Key for the identification of British Erotylidae

Description: A key to the British species of family Geotrupidae, revised to include Odonteus armiger which was formerly placed in a separate family Bolboceratidae. The 2012 version of the Checklist of Beetles of the British Isles lists this species as a member of subfamily Bolboceratinae along with the seven species of subfamily Geotrupinae.
Keywords: Geotrupidae Odonteus armiger Coleoptera earth-boring dung beetles
Title: Key for the identification of British Geotrupidae

Description: The whirligig beetles are familiar to anybody who has had more than a cursory look at still or slow-moving water during the warmer months. They are relatively small, dark coloured beetles that swim round and round in circles, apparently mindlessly, but certainly with their own agenda. In the British Isles there are 12 species (one of which is probably only from Ireland) in two genera. Some of them can be distinguished using characters visible at relatively low power magnification but for others close observation of the fine surface sculpturing of the elytra is required at high magnification. Even then identification will sometimes be tentative without examination of the male or female mating apparatus
Title: Key for the identification of British Gyrinidae

Description: 19 species of this aquatic family are found in Britain. They are placed in three genera, Brychius and Peltodytes both with a single species and Haliplus with all the rest.
Keywords: Haliplidae Brychius Peltodytes Haliplus water beetles
Title: Key for the identification of British Haliplidae

Description: The British members of this family number eight from two genera. They are relatively difficult to identify and may require dissection of the male abdomen to make certain.
Title: Key for the identification of British Heteroceridae

Description: The current check list of British Histeridae (Duff, 2012) lists 52 species from 21 genera and 7 subfamilies. All these species can be identified using the key below although some might require dissection to confirm.
Keywords: Histeridae clown beetles Hister beetles Arthropoda
Title: Key for the identification of British Histeridae

Description: The seven British species of this family are all in genus Hydrochus. They can be identified using the key below.
Title: Key for the identification of British Hydrochidae

Description: The nine British species of this family belong to three genera. Two of them are very common on the flowers of nettles and several others are frequently encountered. They are very small species and will require a good stereomicroscope to identify as in the first couplet you are being asked to find a tooth at the base of the claws. If you have good equipment and lighting, the key below should separate them. The family has been treated in various ways in the past but is closely related to Nitidulidae.
Title: Key for the identification of British Kateretidae

Description: The nine British species of this family belong to three genera. Two of them are very common on the flowers of nettles and several others are frequently encountered. They are very small species and will require a good stereomicroscope to identify as in the first couplet you are being asked to find a tooth at the base of the claws. If you have good equipment and lighting, the key below should separate them. The family has been treated in various ways in the past but is closely related to Nitidulidae.
Keywords: Kateretidae short-winged flower beetles Polyphaga Arthropoda
Title: Key for the identification of British Kateretidae

Description: Twelve species from this family are on the British list. Seven of these are in genus Cryptolestes and include some pests of stored products. The key below should allow the identification of the British fauna.
Title: Key for the identification of British Laemophloeidae

Description: Twelve species from this family are on the British list. Seven of these are in genus Cryptolestes and include some pests of stored products. The key below should allow the identification of the British fauna.
Keywords: Laemophloeidae lined flat bark beetles Cucujoidea
Title: Key for the identification of British Laemophloeidae

Description: These are the so-called glow-worms. We have three species reported from Britain. One has not been recorded for over a century, one is more or less restricted to SE England and the other is widespread. The males and females are very different and the key below will enable identification of both sexes.
Title: Key for the identification of British Lampyridae

Description: The current checklist includes 56 species in 13 genera and 2 subfamilies. Some of the species are very difficult to differentiate partly because they are so small, being only 1-3 mm. The attached file is a first go at the family in the UK, translated from the German keys published online by A. Lompe. It leads to most species, but there are three that I couldn't find characters for differentiation.
Subfamily Latridiinae Subfamily Corticariinae
Lithostygnus Corticaria
Stephostethus Corticarina
Cartodere Cortinicara
Latridius Melanophthalma
Thes Migneauxia
Enicmus
Dienerella
Adistemia
Keywords: minute brown scavenger beetles fungus beetle Arthropoda
Title: Key for the identification of British Latridiidae

Description: A total of 93 species in 20 genera and four subfamilies are on the latest British checklist. The first key enables identification to genus and also includes keys to species of those genera with four or fewer species. A key to the species of genus Leiodes is in progress.
Keywords: Leiodidae Agathidium Choleva Colon Round fungus beetles
Title: Key for the identification of British Leiodidae

Description: A small family in the British fauna. There are four species on the British list but one of these is almost certainly extinct.
Title: Key for the identification of British Lucanidae

Description: A family represented in Britain by four species each in a different genus
Title: Key for the identification of British Lycidae

Description: Two species of this family are present in Britain, associated with dead and dying trees.
Title: Key for the identification of British Lymexylidae

Description: The current check list has 17 species in 11 genera. Some are very rare and as a family the species are more frequent to the south and then become rarer further north. The key below should allow the identification of the British species. As always please contact me about how you get on and if you have improvements to suggest.
Title: Key for the identification of British Malachiidae

Description: The current check list has 17 species in 11 genera. Some are very rare and as a family the species are more frequent to the south and then become rarer further north.
Title: Key for the identification of British Malachiidae

Description: A small family with only three British species, closely related to the Chrysomelidae, differing in the tooth on each side of the pronotum. The key below from Joy (1932) will differentiate them.
Title: Key for the identification of British Megalopodidae

Description: This family contains 17 species on the British list, classified in ten genera and two subfamilies. Buck (1954) published a key to the British species and this is updated with some of the terminology simplified in the illustrated key below.
Subfamily MELANDRYINAE Subfamily OSPHYINAE
ORCHESIA CONOPALPUS
ANISOXYAABDERA OSPHYA
ABDERA
PHLOIOTRYA
XYLITA
HYPULUS
ZILORA
MELANDRYA
Title: Key for the identification of British Melandryidae

Description: The latest checklist lists ten species from three genera. Some of these are very rare. Genus Meloe is the subject of a survey by Buglife - details at http://www.buglife.org.uk/getinvolved/surveys/Oil+Beetle+Hunt. The key below is adapted from Joy (1932) and can be used to identify the British fauna to species. Any of those marked "very rare" should be photographed and sent to Buglife.
Title: Key for the identification of British Meloidae

Description: The latest checklist has 23 species in three genera and two subfamilies. They are quite small beetles most of which are associated with decaying plant material, either under the bark of dying or dead trees or in compost heaps or similar habitats. Two of our species are associated with ants' nests. The three genera are Rhizophagus and Cyanostolus in subfamily Rhizophaginae and genus Monotoma in subfamily Monotominae.
Title: Key for the identification of British Monotomidae

Description: A family of 17 species of quite conspicuous beetles that are generally very difficult to identify. The references in the attached document may give you an indication of where to go next to further study this family. Every text indicates that work is needed to revise this family or at least genera within it.
Title: Key for the identification of British Mordellidae

Description: The key below is for all the UK species listed in the 2012 edition of the Checklist of Beetles of Britain. There are 15 species listed, from 7 genera, most of them associated with fungi. This key is an adaptation of the key in German written by Dr Arved Lompe which is attributed to the work of H. Vogt, E. Reitter, and L. Ganglbauer.
Keywords: hairy fungus beetles Polyphaga fungi Mycetophagidae
Title: Key for the identification of British Mycetophagidae

Description: The Loosestrife weevils - 2 species in Britain, the commoner of which causes spindle-shaped galls in Purple-loosestrife.
The key below will allow their separation but this is easiest by association with the host plant.
Keywords: Apionidae Nanophyes marmoratus Goeze Dieckmanniellus gracilis Redtenbacher
Title: Key for the identification of British Nanophyidae

Description: There are two species of this family of water beetles found in the UK, both found in still water habitats
Title: Key for the identification of British Noteridae

Description: There are ten species on the British list, some of which are conspicuous flower-feeders and so are often noticed. The updated key below should allow identification of all British species although confident diagnosis of some is only possible in males.
The Oedemeridae are one of the groups of beetles with thread-like antennae and a 2-lobed segment on the hind tarsus. Within this group they have this combination of features:
hind leg formed of four segments; front and middle legs with five
head lacking a distinct neck with the back of the head recessed into the thorax
pronotum longer than wide
elytra with three or four distinct longitudinal ridges
elytra usually either not fully covering the abdomen or not meeting along the middle, diverging from one another towards the tip
Keywords: Oedemeridae false blister beetles pollen-feeding beetles
Title: Key for the identification of British Oedemeridae

Description: A small family of just two British species related to the Chrysomelidae, keyed in the document below.
Title: Key for the identification of British Orsodacnidae

Description: The species in this family have been previously placed in two families Anobiidae and Ptinidae but are now combined. The species on the British list are all keyed in the document below although some of it is rather tentative.
Title: Key for the identification of British Ptinidae

Description: There are only three species in this family on the British list and they are keyed in the document below.
Title: Key for the identification of British Pyrochroidae

Description: This is a small family of very similar looking weevils which feed on a number of plants, sometimes at pest levels. There are 17 species listed in the current checklist placed in 9 genera. The key below is derived from those of Lompe and Hoffmann and illustrated using the photographs on Lech Borowiec's site.
Title: Key for the identification of British Rhynchitidae

Description: The species of this family may be found under bark or in the small branches of trees and hedgerow shrubs. The adults and larvae feed on other insects which are living on wood and fungi. Aglenus brunneus is an exception to this - it is found in stored foodstuffs.
Title: Key for the identification of British Salpingidae

Description: In Britain we have one species each from genera Odeles, Microcara, Prionocyphon and Hydrocyphon, two species of Scirtes, four species of Elodes and ten of genus Cyphon.

The file below should allow some progress towards identification. Examination of the genitalia will be necessary for definitive identification of some pairs of species. There are notes on this in the section on genus Cyphon.
Title: Key for the identification of British Scirtidae

Description: This is a small family in the British fauna. The adults are however often collected from the blossom of spring shrubs, particularly hawthorn and those of several species are widespread in Britain. The key below is taken from Buck (1954) and should allow identification of the British species.
Title: Key for the identification of British Scraptiidae

Description: A key to the British genera and species of family Silphidae is available below.
Keywords: Carrion beetles Carrion beetles Silphinae and Nicrophorinae
Title: Key for the identification of British Silphidae

Description: A family with 13 established British species from 10 genera. An additional 16 species are listed in the latest checklist as non-established introductions. These are not included in the key below.
There are two subfamilies represented:
Subfamily Brontinae containing the genera Uleiota, Dendrophagus, Cryptamorpha and Psammoecus
Subfamily Silvaninae containing the genera Cathartus, Nausibius, Ahasverus, Oryzaephilus, Silvanus and Silvanoprus
Title: Key for the identification of British Silvanidae

Description: The species of this family are weevils and were formerly treated as a subfamily of Curculionidae. There are 13 British species placed in seven genera.
Title: Key for the identification of British species of Erirhinidae

Description: A small family with only two species in Britain, Sphindus dubius and Aspidiphorus orbiculatus, two species of completely different form, so easy to identify. The document below separates them
Title: Key for the identification of British Sphindidae

Description: In the current checklist there are 47 species on the British list. These include some species which are only found in domestic situations, often as pests. The delimitation of the family has changed since the publication of the Handbook for the Identification of British Insects by Brendell in 1975. The key below should allow identification of the British fauna.
Title: Key for the identification of British Tenebrionidae

Description: There are four members of this family on the British list, and they are quite easily separated from one another. They are associated with fungi, most often bracket fungi
Title: Key for the identification of British Tetratomidae

Description: There are five species of this family on the British list, Aulonothroscus brevicollis and four species of Trixagus. They are keyed in the file below.
Title: Key for the identification of British Throscidae

Description: Trogidae, sometimes called hide beetles, is a family of beetles with a distinctive warty or bumpy appearance. Found worldwide, the family includes about 300 species contained in four or five genera
Title: Key for the identification of British Trogidae

Description: This family contains five British species, each from different genera. They are relatively easy to separate, and the illustrated file below can be used for that purpose.
Title: Key for the identification of British Trogossitidae

Description: THE Field Centre and its surroundings at Flatford Mill lie away from the East Anglian chalk, on quaternary drifts and alluvium; they are thus poorer in land-snails than the richest and classic localities such as Boxhill and the woods of Kent and Surrey. Nevertheless, a well-planted area with such a diversity of habitats is bound to provide a good species list, and the present records at the Centre show 39 species of shelled land molluscs, that is to say, exclusive of slugs. Land snails are an important group to ecologists, but unfortunately the student beginning ﬁeld work has initial difficulties with the existing reference works. The object of this simple Key is therefore to provide recognition characters and outline drawings of all those species of land snails that have already been taken, or may be expected to turn up from time to time, in the area worked from Flatford Mill. The slugs are already well introduced in the excellent Synopsis by Quick ( I949).
Title: A Key to the Land Snails of the Flatford area, Suffolk

Description: This AIDGAP identification guide is designed to help non-specialists identify the invertebrates found in pools, lakes, streams and rivers. An identification key is included to enable users to identify macroscopic British freshwater animals to their major group and, where possible, to family, genus and species. Designed for use with living specimens in the field, behavioural characters are given particular emphasis, but full morphological descriptions are also included. Characters which require considerable expertise, or expensive equipment, have been avoided.
Title: A key to the major groups of British freshwater invertebrates

Description: Second edition of this popular AIDGAP identification guide is designed to help non-specialists identify the larger (>1mm length) invertebrates found on land throughout the British Isles. An identification key is included to enable non-specialists to identify living animals encountered during field studies in most terrestrial or semi-terrestrial habitats. Designed for use with living specimens, using standard sampling techniques, characters which require considerable expertise, or expensive equipment, have deliberately been avoided. Ecological notes are included for all groups.
Title: A key to the major groups of terrestrial invertebrates

Comment Body: Hi Steve. It's still a work in progress, but if you email Matthew Shepherd he may be willing to send you the latest PDF in return for your feedback. Contact him here: [[email protected]](../cdn-cgi/l/email-protection.html)
Description: This key should help you to identify families of mites found in soil and litter in the UK and Ireland, as well as introduce you to some aspects of mite ecology. The key is under development and testing. If you are interested in helping with the testing, contact Natural England's Matthew Shepherd.
Title: A Key to the Soil Mites of Britain and Ireland

Description: In addition to our native daffodil there are a large number of introduced daffodils growing wild in Britain. Some of these have been deliberately planted, while others have escaped from gardens, usually when soil has been dumped on waysides. This is a key to these daffodils.
Title: A Key to Wild and Introduced Daffodils of Great Britain

Description: The AIDGAP identification guide to woodlice contains keys to the 35 species of woodlice known to be breed outdoors in the British Isles. Colour plates support detailed line drawings and the confirmatory descriptions of each species include notes on distribution and natural history. Illustrated throughout with line drawings of key features as well as 16 colour plates.
Title: A key to the woodlice of Britain and Ireland

Description: RES Handbook vol 4 Part 5b. Illustrated keys are provided for the families, genera, species and other taxa of British and Irish members of the superfamily Hydrophiloidea (Coleoptera suborder Polyphaga). The Hydrophiloidea comprise the families Helophoridae, Georissidae, Hydrochidae, Spercheidae, and the Hydrophilidae. Most of these beetles are aquatic and this book is the second part of the RES Handbook series concerning water beetles. However, this work includes terrestrial Helophorus and many species in the subfamily Sphaeridiinae of the Hydrophilidae. Notes include characters for distinguishing the sexes, basic information on biology and collecting methods, and reviews of distributions in Ireland and in Britain, including the Channel Isles. A key to all families of aquatic beetles is appended.
Keywords: Royal Entomological Society of London FSC entsoc
Title: Keys to adults of the water beetles of Britain and Ireland (Part 2)

Description: The Anthicidae are a family of beetles that resemble ants. They are sometimes called ant-like flower beetles or ant-like beetles.
Title: Keys to the British genera and species of Anthicidae (flower beetles)

Description: This AIDGAP identification guide includes the 34 families of spiders known to occur in Britain (at the time it was written). Designed and tested for use in the field, it should enable the non-specialist to make a positive identification of the spiders that they find. Two spider identification keys are presented. The first is a traditional dichotomous format, using morphological characters that are visible under low-power magnification. The second identification key, a tabular guide, includes a range of behavioural and ecological characters. Sections on spider morphology, biology, ecology and a glossary are also provided.
Title: Keys to families of British spiders

Description: This family was covered by Morris (1990) in Orthocerous Weevils: Coleoptera Curculionoidea (Nemonychidae, Anthribidae, Urodontidae, Attelabidae and Apionidae) (Handbooks for the Identification of British Insects) 5:16. This key is to genus in the British fauna and includes the considerable changes in naming of the genera since Morris' work. See this publication for identification to species. Translated keys are now available here for genera Apion, Perapion and Protapion.
Title: Keys for the identification of British Apionidae

Description: This family was covered by Morris (1990) in Orthocerous Weevils: Coleoptera Curculionoidea. This key is to genus in the British fauna and includes the considerable changes in naming of the genera since Morris' work
Title: Keys for the identification of British Apionidae

Description: Keys to the British genera and species of Cantharidae (soldier beetles)
Keywords: Soldier beetles sailor beetles Podabrus alpinus Cantharinae
Title: Keys for the identification of British Cantharidae

Description: The ground beetles are well represented in the British fauna with 362 species from 87 genera in the 2012 list edited by Duff. Lindroth's keys from 1974 have been well used for nearly four decades and there have been changes made to the generic classification as well as some synonymy. The illustrated key to genus includes the 87 genera in the checklist.
Title: Keys for the identification of British Carabidae

Description: Keys to genera and species of British leaf beetles
Keywords: leaf beetles Bruchinae Donaciinae Criocerinae Cryptocepahalinae
Title: Keys for the identification of British Chrysomelidae

Description: This is a family with a good representation in the British fauna. Unfortunately many of the species are very similar to one another. In addition there does not appear to be any up to date key to the British species so this is an attempt to put that right.
Title: Keys for the identification of British Cryptophagidae

Description: A large family in the British fauna, well covered by Handbooks to the Identification of British Insects by Morris.
The following keys may be used in conjunction with Morris's works. They are translated and adapted from German works.
Title: Keys for the identification of British Curculionidae

Description: This family contains a number of species which are quite similar to one another. The keys below are adapted from translations from the German but are supplemented by my own photographs of specimens I've collected and museum specimens; using these I have sought to clarify some of the characters used.
Keywords: ELATERIDAE DENTICOLLINAE Click beetles spring beetles Arthropoda
Title: Keys for the identification of British Elateridae

Description: The members of this family occurring in Britain all belong to genus Helophorus and most occur in water. We have twenty species on the British list. The key below should allow the identification of the British species. Further details on the British species can be obtained from Keys to adults of the water beetles of Britain and Ireland (Part 2), Foster, Bilton & Friday (2014) available from the Field Studies Council.
Title: Keys for the identification of British Helophoridae

Description: This is a family well-represented in the British fauna with 18 genera and 70 species. The key to genus below contains keys to species of several of the genera. There are separate keys for the large terrestrial genus Cercyon and genus Enochrus.
Title: Keys for the identification of British Hydrophilidae

Description: Subfamilies
Carpophilinae (3 genera, 31 species)
Meligethinae (2 genera, 37 species)
Nitidulinae (7 genera, 14 species)
Cryptarchinae (3 genera, 6 species)
Cybocephalinae (1 species)
Title: Keys for the identification of British Nitidulidae (the pollen beetles)

Description: Tiny beetles of variable shape. Length generally between 0.5 and 1.2 mm; this family includes Europe's smallest beetle (recently found in Britain). As far as is know the larvae and adults feed on fungal spores of a wide range of fungi. Some live in rotting vegetation. Many species are very active flyers. Their wings are feathery and probably do not allow flight in the aerodynamic sense. They are dispersed by wind and thermals.
In the latest checklist there are 18 genera and 75 species listed. The documents below should allow identification to genus and most species.
Title: Keys for the identification of British Ptiliidae

Description: This family includes the dung beetles and flower chafers. Many of the species in this family have experienced great declines in their range over the last century often due to changes in agricultural practice. Up to date information is available on the Dung Beetle UK Mapping Project led by Darren Mann at the Oxford University Museum (https://dungbeetlemap.wordpress.com). Details about how to extract beetles from dung are given at http://www.thewcg.org.uk/pages/dungsampling.htm.
The keys below should enable you to get to grips with the British species. Some indications of rarity are up to date but some are not.
The latest edit below includes a revision of genus Onthophagus based on examination of museum specimens and inclusion of Valgus hemipterus.
Title: Keys for the identification of British Scarabaeidae

Description: This is the largest family of beetles in the UK and includes over 1000 species. It is divided into a number of subfamilies some of which are easily recognisable. The subfamily key below can be used to start your identification. Use the genus keys to take identification further. The six subfamilies with a single representative in the British fauna are keyed in the subfamily key.
Key to genus (except Athetini)
Key to genus (tribe Athetini)
Key to the British species of tribe Falagriini
Key to the British species of tribe Hypocyphtini
Key to the British species of tribe Myllaenini
Key to the British species of tribe Oxypodini
Keywords: Euaesthetinae Habrocerinae Habrocerus capillaricornis Micropeplinae Micropeplus Omaliinae
Title: Keys for the identification of British Staphylinidae

Description: This identification video looks at Whinchat, Stonechat and Wheatear. These three birds are not too difficult to separate in breeding male plumage, but a lot harder in female and juvenile. Check out our tips to help here.
Title: Know your Chats

Description: Song and Mistle Thrush are two garden species that are readily confused; both are grey brown in appearance; both have a spotted breast and pale legs. However, with good views and the right pointers both can be identified with confidence.
Title: Know your thrushes - Song and Mistle

Description: Ladybird larvae are often found, but not well known, as they look so different from adult ladybirds. This 8-panel fold-out chart with illustrations of the larvae of the 26 ladybird species featured on the earlier Ladybirds chart and a selection of photographs of pupae.
Keywords: fold-out, fold out, FSC, field studies council, invertebrates
Title: Ladybird larvae

Description: This atlas describes the distribution of ladybirds in Britain, Ireland, the Isle of Man and the Channel Islands, using data collected through the Biological Records Centre Coccinellidae Recording Scheme (including the UK Ladybird Survey) since 1964. There are 47 species of Coccinellidae resident in Britain and Ireland. Species accounts include distribution maps, photos of adults, larvae and pupae, and details of identification and ecology. Additional guidance is provided on collecting and recording.
Keywords: BRC Biological Records Centre FSC Field Studies Council CEH
Title: Ladybirds (Coccinellidae) of Britain and Ireland

Author(s): Helen E Roy, Peter MJ Brown, Richard F Comont, Remy L Poland, John J Sloggett, Sophie Allington, Chris Shields
Description: This revised and updated edition of Ladybirds provides a succinct but comprehensive and accessible overview of the biology of ladybirds and their parasites, focusing on ecology in an evolutionary context. It provides the latest information, coverage of recent additions to the British list including the harlequin ladybird, and makes suggestions for further research, both short and long term, highlighting gaps in knowledge and showing readers how to get involved with recording and studying ladybirds. It includes updated keys for the identification of ladybirds at late-instar larval and adult stages, and techniques for studying ladybirds and their parasites in both laboratory and field.

The authors hope that Ladybirds will be a valuable resource, not only for students, from school to university and beyond, but also for anyone with an interest in natural history, whether professional or recreational.
Title: Ladybirds

Description: With new colour illustrations for 2012, this guide covers all the main land mammals found in Britain. The text gives further background information on each species.
Keywords: fold-out, fold out, FSC, field studies council
Title: Land mammals of Britain

Description: This fully illustrated AIDGAP identification guide should enable most beginners to identify all the land snails found in the field in Great Britain. Like all other AIDGAP keys, the guide was extensively tested during preparation. The guide contains two sets of keys (pictorial and dichotomous) to families or groups of similar families, and then separate keys to the species within each group. The keys rely mainly on shell characters, allowing the identification of empty shells. A final and separate set of keys is provided for the small number of species where identification requires dissection.
Title: Land snails in the British Isles (2nd edition)

Description: Say no to the mow! Photo guide to the most commonly seen wildflowers in our garden lawns.
Title: Lawn wildflowers

Description: Help scientists track the spread of the horse-chestnut leaf miner moth with this simple, intuitive app.

What is happening to Britain’s horse-chestnut trees? Since 2002 Britain’s conker trees have been under attack from a non-native moth – and you can help scientists monitor what’s happening. The LeafWatch app shows you how to identify affected trees and enables you to submit your geo-located leaf photos. This data will show our scientists where the moth is present within the UK today.
Your reports will contribute to the Conker Tree Science research project. Visit us at http://www.conkertreescience.org.uk/.
Title: LeafWatch

Description: This website contains high-magnification images of the dissected genitalia of macro- and micro-moths. There is also an introductory guide on how to do dissections, and illustrated diagrams of the technical terms used. An essential resource for identifying the more challenging moth species.
Title: Lepidoptera Dissection Group website

Description: An excellent photographic resource - particularly for quality photographs of genitalia. Covers many species found in the UK.
Title: Les araignées de Belgique et de France (Spiders of Belgium and France)

Description: An excellent photographic resource - particularly for quality photographs of genitalia. Covers many species found in the UK.
Title: Les araignées de Belgique et de France (Spiders of Belgium and France)

Author(s): Poulain, Michel, Marianne Meyer et Jean Bozonnet
Description: Information on 853 taxa of myxomycetes (530 of them illustrated by colour photographs) in two complementary volumes, one providing the text and the other the plates. French text , with bilingual keys (French / English).

A section on the general biology and ecology of myxomycetes is followed by species keys, and descriptions - these include macroscopic and microscopic characters cross referenced to the plates. Nomenclature follows the latest version of Nomenmyx. A new genus Meriderma, is proposed and detailed in an addendum where the spores of its species are illustrated.

There is also a glossary of terms, index of taxa, and bibliographical references. The plate volume shows each species in the form of an index card, with scientific name, one or more macro- photographs illustrating the habit of the species, and line drawings of relevant microscopic characters (e.g.spore type, ornamen - tation, etc.). There is extensive coverage of the nivicolous species, a group of which the authors are well-known specialists.
Title: Les myxomycètes

Author(s): Poulain, Michel, Marianne Meyer et Jean Bozonnet
Description: Information on 853 taxa of myxomycetes (530 of them illustrated by colour photographs) in two complementary volumes, one providing the text and the other the plates. French text , with bilingual keys (French / English).

A section on the general biology and ecology of myxomycetes is followed by species keys, and descriptions - these include macroscopic and microscopic characters cross referenced to the plates. Nomenclature follows the latest version of Nomenmyx. A new genus Meriderma, is proposed and detailed in an addendum where the spores of its species are illustrated.

There is also a glossary of terms, index of taxa, and bibliographical references. The plate volume shows each species in the form of an index card, with scientific name, one or more macro- photographs illustrating the habit of the species, and line drawings of relevant microscopic characters (e.g.spore type, ornamen - tation, etc.). There is extensive coverage of the nivicolous species, a group of which the authors are well-known specialists.
Title: Les myxomycètes

Description: This mobile app is a tool for assessing the status of nitrogen in your area by surveying lichen on trees. By identifying the presence or absence of 9 nitrogen sensitive and 8 non-sensitive lichens on tree trunks and branches you can get an estimate of how polluted your area is.
Title: Lichen App for assessing Nitrogen pollution

Description: This fold-out chart covers 62 of the species found on heaths and moors, organised into species that grow on the ground, among grasses and mosses, on heather, and on small rocks and pebbles. Lichens are present throughout the year and may be searched for at any time.
Keywords: fold-out, fold out, FSC, field studies council
Title: Lichens of heaths and moors

Author(s): Pat Wolseley; Diccon Alexander; Peter James; Anne Hume; Harry Taylor
Description: This site provides a user-friendly guide to over 60 lichens which can be found growing on twigs. With the help of our fully illustrated multi-access key we hope you will find identification of these unique organisms easy and fun.
Lichens are extremely sensitive to pollution and are natural indicators of the health of our environment.
This interactive identification guide was developed by Museum scientists Pat Wolseley, Diccon Alexander, Peter James and Anne Hume, with photographs by Harry Taylor.
This guide is part of the AIDGAP project that produces user tested guides to animals and plants. You can obtain hard copy versions to take in the field with you from:
Title: Lichens on twigs

Description: This 8-panel fold-out chart is designed to enable you to identify lichens found on twigs and use them to assess local atmospheric conditions. Lichens are highly sensitive to subtle changes in environmental conditions, so are natural indicators of the health of our environment.
This key indicates which lichens are acid-tolerant and nitrogen-tolerant and also indicates lichens that are associated with unpolluted sites.
Title: Lichens on twigs

Description: Superb illustrations produced by Ashley Wood allow easy comparison between the life stages of a range of UK shieldbug species. They are particularly useful for identifying nymphs, and the various instars are depicted as far as possible. Each plate is linked to the relevant species account, which provides further information.
Title: Lifestages of British shieldbugs

Description: List of British species with their food plants
Title: List of British species with their food plants

Author(s): P. E. KING and G. B. CRAPP
Description: Keys to the littoral pycnogonids of the British Isles are presented. Brief notes concerning distribution, possible food sources and the validity of each species are included. The Nymphonidae are considered in relation to the species which occur in other parts of the Atlantic and evidence presented to demonstrate the validity of the three species Nymphon gracile, N. rubrum and N. brevirostre.
Title: Littoral Pycnogonids Of The British Isles

Description: This Synopsis contains keys and details accounts for the identification of lobsters, mud shrimps and anomuran crabs. It covers the Decapod Crustacea not included in Synopses 15 and 25. With the publication of this volume, it is now possible to identify all the larger crustaceans found in shallow water around British coasts.
Keywords: Synopses of the British Fauna linsoc Linnean Society FSC
Title: Lobsters, mud shrimps and anomuran crabs

Author(s): Wil j. Heeney; Katy Potts; Richard Lewington
Description: Covering 42 British species, the Longhorn Beetles Identification Chart is the first popular guide for many years to these large and colourful insects. Almost all species can be identified in the field - most don't even need a hand lens. Beautiful colour illustrations by Richard Lewington accompany a comprehensive species feature table covering the status, distribution, habitat and size of each species featured. Produced in association with the National Longhorn Beetle Recording Scheme.
Title: Longhorn Beetles Identification Chart

Description: Comprehensive electronic multiaccess key to the vascular plants of the British Isles, available for desktop computers and as an Android app
Keywords: Flora, key, identification, vascular plants, flowering plants, trees, flowers, multiaccess
Title: MAKAQueS

Description: Photo guide to the most commonly seen wildflowers in March.
Title: March Wildflowers Spotter’s Sheet

Description: Photo guide to the most commonly seen wildflowers in March.
Title: March Wildflowers Spotter’s Sheet

Description: The order Harpacticoida is one of the ten orders of the sub-class Copepoda which, along with six other sub-classes, make up the class Maxillopoda, one of the classes of the lower Crustacea. Most species are free-swimming in marine or brackish water, although a few are ectoparasitic or commensal. The marine harpacticoids are primarily bottom-living copepods, although a few are exclusively planktonic, and are most abundant in soft sediments and on macro-algae. There are approximately 800 species belonging to around 190 genera of marine harpacticoids occurring in the waters around the British Isles. This Synopsis provides keys to generic level for the sub-order Polyarthra and 14 families of the sub-order Oligoarthra.
Keywords: Synopses of the British Fauna linsoc Linnean Society FSC
Title: Marine and brackish water Harpacticoid Copepods (Part 1)

Description: The Ostracoda are a sub-class of relatively small crustaceans which occur in most aquatic habitats. Many aquatic biologists can recognise an ostracod as such but comparatively few can identify one to species level. The main problem has been the lack of a modern guide which this Synopsis addresses for offshore marine groups.
Keywords: Synopses of the British Fauna linsoc Linnean Society FSC
Title: Marine planktonic Ostracods

Description: A guide to the diagnostic features of Equisetum palustre (Marsh Horsetail) to aid in the identification of the species.
Title: Marsh horsetail - ID video

Description: Photo guide to the most commonly seen wildflowers in May

Description: Photo guide to 6 species of UK jellyfish plus 2 species of Hydrozoa (Portuguese man-of-war and By the wind sailor) to help beach goers and sea users report sightings as part of the Marine Conservation Society's Jellyfish Survey
Title: MCS Jellyfish Guide

Description: This new 12 panel fold-out chart showcases the wildlife of the Meres and Mosses landscape of Shropshire, Cheshire and Staffordshire. Although not well known outside the local area, this landscape has the largest groups of natural lakes and wetlands in England and the highest density of ponds anywhere in Europe.
Keywords: fold-out, fold out, FSC, field studies council
Title: Meres and Mosses

Description: This fold-out chart is designed to aid the identification of moorland and heathland plants in the British Isles. Arranged by habitat, the chart includes plants of peat bogs (such as bog asphodel and bog myrtle), wet heath (such as cross-leaved heath and sundews), dry heath (such as cowberry and bilberry) and upland woodland (such as gorse and foxglove).

The chart is suitable for students (14+) carrying out fieldwork in moorland or heathland, such as wet-dry transects, surveys of heather management and studies of heathland succession. The key uses non-flowering parts of the plant and should be applicable at most times of the year, even when plants are not in flower.
Title: Moorland Plants

Author(s): Moors for the Future, Natural Apptitude Ltd
Description: This app is primarily a field guide to the Sphagnum mosses found in the Peak District National Park and South Pennines and focuses on 12 of the species that you are most likely to see. It also covers several other common moss species, along with some of the more striking lichen and liverwort species you are likely to encounter.
Title: MoorMOSS app

Description: A printable pdf to help identify the plants you encounter on the Peak District and South Pennine peatlands and moors. The document provides text descriptions and photos to help you put a name to many of the characteristic, interesting plants found in the area. It also provides information about the work being done by the Moors for the Future Partnership on the MoorLIFE project and how this is helping to restore and preserve moorland habitats of European importance.
Title: MoorPLANTS pdf

Description: This printable PDF is a field guide to some of the most common and/or iconic moorland animal species found within the Peak District National Park and South Pennine moors.

This document will enable you to get a good feel for the types of birds, reptiles, mammals and insects you are likely to encounter on a walk across the moors. With text that covers key features and photos for each species you will soon be putting a name to the animals that make our moors such a unique place.

The resource also provides information about the work being done by the Moors for the Future Partnership, within the MoorLIFE project, and how this is helping to restore and preserve moorland habitats of European importance.
Title: MoorWILD pdf

Description: The want of a field guide has for many years greatly hindered further spread of interest in British and Irish field bryology. By filling this gap in the market, the guide has made a group that has largely been the realm of specialists into an accessible and popular interest for naturalists, reaching far beyond the current pool of bryologists, and into the wider community of naturalists beyond. Indeed, the guide makes an attractive, modestly priced Christmas or birthday gift for friends and relatives who are or might become interested in bryophytes. The BBS has published the guide, minimizing the price.

This book is the only up-to-date, user-friendly guide to identifying British and Irish bryophytes in the field, with hundreds of colour photographs and black and white drawings showing what species look like, together with notes on how to identify and distinguish similar species, and habitat notes and distribution maps showing where they occur.
Title: Mosses and Liverworts of Britain and Ireland a field guide

Description: Photographic guide accessing UKMoths.org.uk and distribution maps from the National Moth Recording Scheme when online. Covers 2,147 species of lepidoptera found in Britain and Ireland. Photographs of most of the micro and macro moths, including butterflies as well as eggs, larvae and pupae, leaf-mines and characteristic plant damage of some species.
Title: Moths & Butterflies of Britain & Ireland

Comment Body: The link for this site is not working (at November 2017) and I can't find a replacement link anywhere.
Description: Online illustrated key to world diptera families, plus keys to species for some Muscidae genera and various other fly families.

This is an experimental resource being developed by Leif Karlsson. They are worth a try as they are based on existing keys with lots of helpful illustrations added. But treat these keys with a little caution as it has not yet been extensively tested.
Title: Mydiptera by Leif Karlsson Online Diptera keys

Description: Out of print but second-hand copies may be available at a price.
Title: The myxomycetes of Britain and Ireland: an identification handbook

Description: Description

Since its first publication in 1991, New Flora of the British Isles has become established as the standard work on the identification of the wild vascular plants of the British Isles. The Flora remains unique in many features, including its full coverage of all British wild plants. It is a technical authoritative book which has become the 'industry standard' with up to date taxonomy. It is a meaty tome with over 1200 pages, few whole plant illustrations and no colour pictures - not for the faint hearted. 4,800 taxa are now covered in varying degrees of detail. It also incorporates the new molecular system of classification based on DNA sequences. Furthermore, it includes 1600 species illustrations, rewritten distributions and an overhaul of the designation of degrees of rarity, with the introduction of a third, less rare, category. It is often on offer at Summerfield books - who offer a discount to BSBI members.
Title: New Flora of the British Isles

Additional web link: [Guide to Life on Sandy Shores between C](<http://www.record-lrc.co.uk/Downloads/Complete Beach Guide March 2012 compressed2[18042012].pdf>)
Description: This is a great additional help identifying marine wildlife other than those with shells, based on surveys between Fleetwood and Colwyn Bay. It isstill useful to other areas of UK beaches. It covers; Crabs and mobile Crustacea, Barnacles, Tube worms, Oysters, Hydroids and Bryozoa, Sponges, Urchins, Brittle Starfish, some seaweeds, eggs and egg capsules, Sea Squirts and Sea Slugs and borers of holes in shells rocks and wood. An impressive list!
Keywords: shore seaweeds, bryozoans, barnacles, Liverpool seashore Crabs and mobile Crustacea, Barnacles, Tube worms, Oysters, Hydroids and Bryozoa, Sponges, Urchins, Brittle Starfish, seaweeds, eggs aegg capsules, Sea Squirts Sea Slugs borers
Title: Animals other than Shells

Description: Hydroids and their medusae are amongst the most exquisitely beautiful and intriguing of marine invertebrate groups. Because of the large number of groups and species involved, this Synopsis is divided into two parts. Part One: Introduction, the minor families and Haleciidae. Part Two: The hydroid families with larger colonies Sertulaeiidae, Plumulariidae, Aglaopheniidae and Campanulariidae.
Keywords: Synopses of the British Fauna linsoc Linnean Society FSC
Title: North-west European thecate hydroids and their medusae (part 1)

Title: Online key to Bee-flies (Bombyliidae) of North-west Europe

Description: This key to common species of lichens on trees was prepared in collaboration between two partners of the European project KeyToNature (www.keytonature.eu), the Natural History Museum of London and the University of Trieste, as a further aid to the Open Air Laboratories (OPAL) Air Survey which looks at lichens as indicators of air quality.

Description: Field key to the common species of UK earthworms devised as part of the engaging Soil and Earthworm survey. Great resource for use as part of the survey and engaging children with earthworm taxonomy and ecology.

ID limitations: covers less than half of UK earthworm species. Records determined using this resource are not accepted by the National Earthworm Recording Scheme. See the ESB 'Limitations of the OPAL Earthworm Guide for Speices Identification' webpage for a full explanation.

Title: Opiliones in the UK and Continental Europe

Title: Opiliones Wiki

Description: Orchid Id will help you identify and record the wild orchids of the British Isles. All species native to the British Isles are covered.
Title: Orchid Id - The British Orchid Identification Guide

Description: March is a month neglected by many moth trappers. The evenings and nights still tend to be on the cold side of being mild, but there are still moths flying and waiting to be caught. This lack of observer coverage means that we still don't have the complete picture of many early Spring moths distribution.

The relatively small number of species flying in the early months of the year allows plenty of time to quickly learn the five commoner species. Clouded Drab, Hebrew Character, Common, Small and Twin-spotted Quaker.

In the following species descriptions, we have listed the main identification features to help those new to moths and moth trapping. The most likely confusion for the beginner, can be Common Quakers at the smaller-end of the size scale, which at first may be mistaken for Small Quaker
Title: Orthosia (Quaker) Moth identification

Description: All the information on the UKs Newts, includes their food, mating and hibernation habits as well as their protected status.
Title: Our Guide to Newts found in the UK

Description: Produced in conjunction with the Hawk and Owl Trust, this chart is both an identification guide to owls and a practical resource for investigating owl pellets.

Included are colour paintings of the 5 species of owl permanently resident in the British Isles, shown both perched and in flight, illustrations and written descriptions of the different pellets produced by each species of owl and by other birds (kestrel, sparrowhawk, gull and corvids) that could be confused, and a systematic identification key to the contents of owl pellets, including complete skulls, jaws, teeth and other recognisable bones and animal parts.

Text on the reverse side provides background information on the taxonomy of owls, their adaptations for hunting, food chains and conservation status. Further identification information for each species - body length, wingspan, call, habitat, UK breeding range, main prey and conservation status - is given in a table. Guidance is also included on where pellets can be found and how they can be prepared and dissected.
Keywords: fold-out, fold out, FSC, field studies council
Title: Owls and owl pellets

Title: Pdf key to British Silphidae

Description: This FSC fold-out chart is designed to help you identify the indicator species needed to carry out a Phase 1 habitat survey of grassland and marsh habitats, following the guidelines set out in the JNCC Handbook.
Title: Phase 1 survey guide: Grassland and marsh

Description:
It is generally known that Great Diving Beetles are some of our largest freshwater insects and most naturalists
will know the name Dytiscus marginalis, but there are in fact 6 species of Dytiscus in Britain and Ireland as well as two other beetles which can potentially be confused with them. The object of this photo guide is to explain that confusion and allow accurate identification so that the average naturalist can record them.
Keywords: aquatic freshwater ponds rivers streams coleoptera
Title: A Photo Key to Great Diving Beetles

Comment Body: What an excellent couple of guides from Adrian Chalkey. Looking forward to yet more - well done to all
Description: Whilst identification to species of many of the smaller aquatic bugs can be complicated, those described here are fairly straightforward. With a couple of exceptions all of these species are relatively large and are so distinctive in shape that identification to family is very easy. Many of these families only have one species living in the British Isles and those where there are more than one can be separated with the aid of only a hand lens.
Keywords: aquatic freshwater ponds rivers streams hemiptera heteroptera
Title: A Photo Key to Large Aquatic Bugs

Description: This photo atlas and ID guide for Asilidae – robber-flies - of Europe has more than 1,900 photographs of 82 robber-fly species and is based on material examined in private as well as public collections. An attempt was made to photograph the most important features of all species. It includes all UK species.
Title: Photographic atlas and identification key to the robber flies of Germany

Description: Ephemeroptera, also known as mayflies or up-wing flies, can be seen emerging from the water, resting on nearby vegetation and most commonly 'dancing' above head height, along the shores if many still waters and rivers. This guide provides introductory picture-based keys and species accounts for both the adults and nymphs of the 51 species of Ephemeroptera that have been recorded in the British Isles.
Title: A Pictorial Guide to British Ephemeroptera

Description: From the PDF: "There are large number of conifers to be found in plantations, Woodland, shelter belts, hedgerows, copses, parks, cemeteries and churchyards throughout our islands (a provisional checklist is given by C. Crook (1997) BSBI News 75: 42-47). They are found in important areas for conservation and should be properly recorded. The following key includes all those species I think are most likely to be found in these places. It can be used in conjunction with Mitchell (1978). It has been written aﬁer I have spent the winter looking at living specimens of many of the species."
Title: The Plant Crib: Conifers

Author(s): T. C. G. Rich & A. C. Jermy (eds)
Description: The Plant Crib (1998) evolved from earlier publications and was prepared to facilitate plant identification and recording of the British Flora, in particular providing guidance on problematic and difficult groups. Some 350 taxonomic groups are covered. Invaluable to all field botanists and ecologists, it contains a vast amount of practical help and guidance and its wealth of drawings and comparative tables for similar species and hybrids are not matched elsewhere. Available as a series of downloadable PDFs from the BSBI website and as a book from Summerfield Books.
Title: The Plant Crib

Description: A to Z of plant and fungi species, with photos, brief description, distribution, habitat, facts and conservation status. Not a complete checklist.
Title: Plant & fungi species

Author(s): Wilson, M., Stewart, A., Biederman, R., Nickel, H., Niedringhaus, R.
Description: Identification keys to all families and genera and all British and Irish species not recorded from Germany. Text English. Supplement to the main work on 'Planthoppers and Leafhoppers of Germany' (Biedermann & Niedringhaus, 2009); this volume includes details of the 19 additional species recorded from Britain and Ireland, but not included in the main work, as well as a comprehensive checklist with synonyms and detailed notes, family and genus keys
Title: The Planthoppers and Leafhoppers of Britain and Ireland

Description: Arranged by habitat with distance from high-tide level, this chart shows 43 common species of plants found in sand dunes. These include strand-line and embryo dune species (such as sea sandwort and saltwort), plants found growing in mobile dunes (such as marram grass and sea holly), plants found in semi-fixed dunes (such as red fescue) and the plants of fixed dunes (such as creeping buttercup). Plants found growing in dune slacks (such as creeping willow) are also included.

The reverse of the chart features a key based on the non-flowering parts of the illustrated plants, allowing plants to be identified even when not in flower. Both a glossary with concise definitions of technical terms and line drawings to support the definitions are included. This chart is suitable for GCSE and AS/A2 fieldwork investigations.
Title: Plants common on sand dunes

Author(s): EA, Scottish Natural Heritage, the Scottish Environment Protection Agency, NatureLocator, CEH.
Description: Identification of UK invasive non-native species. Also includes recording function to submit records of INNS. Website or app.
Title: PlantTracker

Description: Playing fields can be a great place for science investigations. This chart is designed to help 11-14 year olds design and carry out simple ecological investigations in a familiar and accessible habitat.

Colour illustrations by Carol Roberts show a small selection of plants common in playing fields and lawns, with a straightforward guide to leaf shape, flower shape and colour, and other key identification features.

The text side takes students step by step through a full investigation from planning, recording in the field to considering their results. A 'Further Investigations' section suggests extension work which may also be helpful for KS4.
Title: Playing field plants

Description: This handy pocket-sized book has become the essential guide to identifying the butterflies of Great Britain and Ireland. It contains over 600 superb illustrations of the life stages of each species, together with beautiful artworks of butterflies in their natural settings and pertinent species information, distribution maps and life history charts. A selection of day-flying moths is also included for comparison. Presented in an accessible, easy-to-use field-guide format, this is an ideal guide for beginners, as well as for more experienced butterfly enthusiasts. This second edition has been fully revised and features a new, illustrated 'at-a-glance' identification guide to species within families, updated distribution maps and species accounts, as well as new spreads and artwork for the Cryptic Wood White and Scarce Tortoiseshell.
Title: Pocket Guide to the Butterflies of Great Britain and Ireland (2nd edition)

Description: Polychaetes are one of the most widespread, abundant and diverse elements of the British - and indeed the world - marine fauna. They dominate many habitat types, occur in or on all types of substratum, in waters of all levels of salinity, and at all depths in the ocean. This Synopsis, the first in a planned series on the class Polychaeta (phylum Annelida), covers the groups known in older literature as the amphinomids, spintherids and eunicids – groups including genera notoriously difficult to identify.
Keywords: Synopses of the British Fauna linsoc Linnean Society FSC
Title: Polychaetes: British Amphinomida, Spintherida and Eunicida

Description: The minute polychaetes that occur in the interstitial spaces within sandy marine sediments are a diverse phylogenetic assemblage, representing seven separate orders (all of them specifically interstitial) and nine families. Since they occur together in the same microhabitat, this Synopsis departs from the general style and content of the other Synopses devoted to polychaetes, which are each concerned with one group of related species or families. This new edition of the Synopsis has been brought completely up to date, with many new references, an updated species list, and extensive additional information included about species featured in the First edition.
Keywords: Synopses of the British Fauna linsoc Linnean Society FSC
Title: Polychaetes: Interstitial families (2nd ed.)

Description: A video guide (short YouTube film) to the diagnostic features of the Poppies commonly found in Britain and Ireland to aid in the identification of the species.
Title: Poppies - video ID key

Description: Based on approximately 14000 records, covering over 300 species, this is the first ever published atlas of the bees, wasps and ants in Shropshire.

Shropshire is a large inland county containing a great deal of habitat diversity within its boundaries. Significant areas for bees, wasps and ants include ash landfill in Buildwas, old sand quarries in Morville and Cound, lowland heath in Ruyton XI Towns and Prees, and flower-rich woodland in Wyre Forest and Wenlock Edge. The authors have discovered churchyards and suburban gardens with a rich aculeate fauna in Shrewsbury, Oswestry and Craven Arms. Good lists have also been made for coniferous plantations in the Clun district, the upland heath of the Long Mynd, and lowland grassland and arable fields in the north of the county.
This atlas is one of a number being published to examine the distribution of some of Shropshire’s invertebrate groups as a result of the HLF Invertebrate Challenge project.
Keywords: Aculeate hymenoptera, distribution maps, Shropshire, Invertebrate Challenge, FSC
Title: A provisional atlas of the bees, wasps and ants of Shropshire

Description: Published by NERC 1993 atlas and key
Title: Provisional atlas of the ptychopterid craneflies (Diptera: Ptychopteridae) of Britain and Ireland

Description: Shieldbugs have been little studied in Shropshire until very recently. Since 2009, a concerted effort has been made to map their distribution in the county, resulting in over 3000 new records. Along with a number of historical records from a range of sources, these form the basis of this new county atlas. Both true shieldbugs (Pentatomoidea) and their allies the squashbugs, leatherbugs, spurge bugs and scentless plant bugs (Coreoidea) are included.

Shropshire is a large inland county containing a great deal of habitat diversity within its boundaries. Much of the county is rural. Lowland North Shropshire, with its outstanding Meres and Mosses landscape, contrasts with uplands of the Shropshire Hills in the south. The River Severn, flowing right across the county from west to south-east, is an important ecological corridor for many animals, including shieldbugs.

This atlas is one of a number to be published examining the distribution of some of Shropshire’s invertebrate groups. The atlases follow an upsurge in entomological interest in Shropshire that has been encouraged by the Invertebrate Challenge Project, funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund.
Keywords: Distribution maps, invertebrate challenge, FSC, Shropshire
Title: A provisional atlas of the shieldbugs and alies of Shropshire

Description: RES Handbook vol 1 part 7. Since the first edition of this Handbook was published in 1974 seven new species of Psocoptera have been recorded in Britain. In this revised Handbook a general introduction to the classification, relationships, biology and external morphology of the Psocoptera is followed by notes on their collection and study. An updated checklist of species recorded from the British Isles includes 98 species, with representatives of 19 families. Keys to all families, genera and species, together with diagnostic illustrations, are provided to facilitate identification, and comment provided also on non-British species which may cause confusion.
Keywords: Royal Entomological Society of London FSC entsoc
Title: Psocids Psocoptera (Booklice and Barklice)

Description: Quick ID Guide to ants designed to be used on a beginners ant course but also available as a download as well. It is intended to get people looking at ants more closely, and making the first steps towards identifying the species.
Title: Quick ant guide

Description: An on-line, digital flash card learning resource covering 28 wader species known to occur in Britain and Ireland on a regular basis. It includes wader silhouettes by Mike Langman and photographs by Keith Offord. It is part of an integrated suite of wader resources which also includes Identikit, a multi-access digital identification key, and WildID Waders of Britain and Ireland fold out guide.
Title: Quizlet Waders of Britain and Ireland

Description: This 8-page laminated fold-out chart includes 13 species of non-marine reptile and amphibian which breed in Britain, and the 5 species which breed in Ireland. These include frogs, toads, newts, snakes and lizards.
Title: Reptiles and amphibians of Britain and Ireland

Author(s): Lt-Col. F. C. Fraser, I M S
Description: THE ODONATA or Dragonflies are insects familiar to everyone, and, if we except a few of the larger Neuroptera or Lacewings, there are few insects in this country with which they may be confused. They may be described as large or medium-sized four-winged insects, aerial in habit and amphibious by nature since, apart from the short imaginal stage, they spend the greater part of their lives in water; they are predacious on other insects which they capture when on the wing. The sexes are of the same size, but frequently differ in colour and markings, and although the newly emerged or "teneral" male often resembles the female, this resemblance is lost after a few days on the wing.
Keywords: res handbooks out of print dragonflies damselflies
Title: RES Handbook Vol 1 Part 10. Odonata

Author(s): L. A. Mound, G. D. Morison, B. R. Pitkin & J. M. Palmer
Description: The term 'British species' may be interpreted in different ways. In the Formicidae 'native' species and a few firmly established or regular immigrants are considered under this title; however, in groups such as the Psocoptera all species which have been collected in the British Isles are regarded as 'British species'. The latter interpretation has been adopted in the present handbook. Many Thysanoptera are transported by air currents and it is not always easy to differentiate between these natural immigrant species and those species which have been accidentally introduced by man.
Keywords: res handbooks out of print thrips
Title: RES Handbook Vol 1 Part 11. Thysanoptera

Description: The last major review of the British Hydroptilidae was made by Mosely (1939), who described the males and ten females of the 27 species then known in his handbook to the British Trichoptera. Hydroptila lotensis Mosely and Ithytrichia clavata Morton have since been added to the list, while Kimmins (1958) reviewed the British species of the genus Oxyethira (excluding mirabilis Morton), re-illustrating the male genitalia and describing the females of all but distinctella McLachlan for the first time. Apart from Kimmins's (1966) checklist, and Macan's (1973) key to the British Trichoptera, which simply reproduces Mosely's (1939) and Kimmins's (1958, 1961) original figures, very little has been published lately on adult hydroptilids. Recent studies on the family (Marshall, 1977) have added two more species to the British list, Hydroptiia martini Marshall and H. valesiaca Schmid, which were both previously confused with H. occulta (Eaton), so that the total number now stands at 31.
Keywords: caddisflies res handbooks out of print
Title: RES Handbook Vol 1 Part 14a. Trichoptera, Hydroptilidae

Description: FLEAS are small (1-8 mm long), wingless insects with a holometabolous metamorphosis (egg-larva-pupa-adult); their bodies are strongly compressed laterally, usually heavily sclerotised, hairy and shiny and light-rufous to almost black in colour. They are parasitic in the adult stage only, sucking blood from mammals and birds. The larvae are legless, elongate, eyeless, with fairly sparse but strong bristles and they have biting mouth-parts; they are not parasitic, but feed on organic matter which they find mainly in their usual abode, the nest or dwelling-place of the host. The free pupa is contained in a cocoon.
Title: RES Handbook Vol 1 Part 16. Siphonaptera

Description: THE Thysanura and Diplura comprise two of the four Orders of primitively wingless insects or Apterygota. The Diplura, formerly known as the Entognatha , were formerly ranked as a Sub-Order of the Thysanura but have more recently been given full ordinate status. The Thysanura, sensu stricto, were at that time attributed to the Sub-Order Ectognatha.
Keywords: res handbooks out of print silverfish bristletails
Title: RES Handbook Vol 1 Part 2. Thysanura and Diplura

Description: THE Orders Dermaptera and Orthoptera are usually treated together, as a matter of convenience, in dealing with limited faunas such as our own.
Keywords: res handbooks out of print grasshoppers earwigs
Title: RES Handbook Vol 1 Part 5. Dermaptera and Orthoptera

Description: RATHER weakly chitinized insects with two pairs of membranous wings often reduced in the male. Antennae filiform, long, mouth-parts of biting type. Legs with only three tarsal segments. Abdomen terminating in a pair of jointed cerci, which may be reduced to one or two segments. Male genitalia diverse in form, differing considerably in the different genera.
