Description: Full copy of this classic text and key to UK Harvestmen, published by the Linnean Society in 1989. Slightly out of date now - has been updated but this is the only edition available online.
Title: Synopsis of the British Fauna No. 4 (2nd edn) Harvestmen

Description: A UK-based project to help promote the recording and study of tachinid flies (Diptera, Tachinidae). We collate records of any tachinids seen in the UK and can provide identifications of photos and specimens, by request and where possible.
Title: Tachinid Recording Scheme

Description: This video rounds up the identification of other Terns - Roseate, Sandwich and Little Tern.
Title: Taking a look at terns: Roseate, Sandwich and Little Tern

Description: This short film takes you through the differences between common and arctic terns.
Title: Taking a look at terns video: Common and Arctic Tern

Description: A video guide (short YouTube film) to the diagnostic features of the Tasselweeds, Ruppia cirrhosa and R. maritima, to aid in the identification of the species
Title: Tasselweeds - ID video

Description: Of the more common species in the UK, Marsh and Willow Tit probably present one of the more difficult ID challenges. View our Bird ID video to gain some invaluable tips on key features to tell them apart.
Title: Telling apart Marsh and Willow Tits

Description: A series of PDFs tackling grasses. Each of them two pages designed to be printed double-sided and laminated for taking into the field. Ideal for helping people to learn grasses. (The links to them are collected together at the end of the BSBI page for the Plant Crib.)
Title: The TEP files

Author(s): Laurence Mound, Dom Collins, Anne Hastings
Description: This identification and information system includes 177 species of thrips that have been taken alive on the British Isles at least once. It provides a means of identifying species, together with an introduction to what is known of the biology and distribution of each species. The identification system is based largely on adult females as this is the life stage most commonly collected.
Title: Thysanoptera Britannica et Hibernica: Thrips of the British Isles

Description: This fold-out chart is designed to help with the identification of the majority of bird species likely to be found in a British garden throughout the year. Choose the colour of the bird and its size, and you should be able to put a name to it. Different forms for males, females and juveniles are shown where appropriate to help with identification.
The choice of 'top 50' is based on the relative abundance of species recorded in the UK by the BTO Garden BirdWatch survey, and should make garden bird identification quick and painless!
Keywords: fold-out, fold out, FSC, field studies council
Title: Top 50 garden birds: British garden bird identification

Description: Produced with the support of the Forestry Commission, this 12-page laminated fold-out chart contains a full-colour illustrated key to the leaves, twigs, fruits and seeds of the commonest broadleaved and coniferous trees of Britain and Ireland.
To further help with tree identification, a comprehensive table gives more information about the bark characteristics, flowers, common habitats, origin and economic uses of the trees illustrated.
Title: Tree name trail

Description: This field guide contains a collection of photographs of everything you need to identify a tree - whether in winter, spring, summer or autumn. Every species has a photograph of a whole tree, plus close-ups of its bark, buds, leaves, male or female flowers, and fruit. The photographs are backed up with text describing what to look for to differentiate one similar looking species from another. It covers over 800 species of tree - every species that is native to Europe, plus all the species that are commonly planted in parks and gardens.
Title: Trees of Britain and Europe

Description: A guide to the identification of all tree species found in Britain and northern Europe. Showing leaf, bud, flower, fruit and bark detail, as well as views of the entire tree at various points in its annual cycle, this guide will enable the user to identify easily and confidently any tree found in the region, at any time of the year. A useful gazetteer lists sites where especially fine specimens of many species can be seen in Britain and Ireland.
Title: Trees of Britain and Northern Europe

Description: RES Handbook vol 5 part 17b. An introduction is given to the weevils of subfamilies Raymondionyminae to Smicronychinae, designated as part of the 'true weevils' (family Curculionidae). Summaries are given of the biology, life-history and phenology, economic importance, distribution and conservation of the species covered. This volume includes illustrated keys to the subfamilies of British Curculionidae, and to the species covered in this Handbook. The entry for each species includes characters for distinguishing the sexes, and information on the biology, larval foodplants, distribution within the British Isles and zoogeographic range. Those species with 'Red Data Book' status are indicated.
Keywords: Royal Entomological Society of London FSC entsoc
Title: True weevils (part 1) Coleoptera: Curculionidae

Description: RES handbook vol 5 part 17c. This second volume of the British 'True Weevils' deals with the subfamily Ceutorhynchinae. Illustrated keys for the identification of the tribes, genera and species are provided. Notes are provided for each species and include characters for distinguishing the sexes, information on the biology, larval foodplants, distribution within Britain and Ireland and zoogeographic range. Those species with current 'Red Data Book' or 'Notable' status are indicated.
Keywords: Royal Entomological Society of London FSC entsoc
Title: True Weevils (part 2) Coleoptera: Curculionidae, Ceutorhynchinae

Description: RES Handbook Vol 5 Part 17d. This Handbook is the third, and final, part covering the 'true weevils'. Illustrated keys are provided for the identification of the genera and species of the Curculioninae (excluding Ellescini-Dorytomina, Cionini, Smicronychini and Styphlini), Baridinae and Orobatidinae. Notes on the species include characters for distinguishing the sexes and information on th biology, larval foodplants, distribution within Great Britain and Ireland, and zoogeographical range. The species with current 'Red Data Book' or 'Notable' status are indicated.
Keywords: Royal Entomological Society of London FSC entsoc curculionidae
Title: True Weevils (Part III)

Description: A vidoe guide (short YouTube film) to the diagnostic features of Tufted Forget-me-not, to aid in the identification of the species.
Title: Tufted Forget-me-not - ID video

Description: Facebook group devoted to the identification and recording of UK hymenoptera (bees, wasps and ants).
Title: UK Bees, Wasps and Ants

Description: Identification guides (photo based) to UK butterflies, arranged by family.
Title: UK Butterflies

Description: This Facebook group is to enjoy and share information about those species of Dragonflies & Damselflies which are found in the British Isles.
Title: UK Dragonflies & Damselflies

Description: UK Harvestmen (Opiliones) Facebook group, with group members sharing photos, ID help and signposting to courses and additional info.
Title: UK Harvestmen (Opiliones) Facebook group

Description: Album of photos of UK Harvestmen, covering all UK species.
Title: UK Harvetmen Flickr album

Description: Online guide to the moths of Great Britain and Ireland. Lots of photos.
Title: UK Moths

Description: Rocky shore communities has been used in draft form for many years by student visitors to FSC Field Centres. It includes large annotated images of four communities at different levels of the shore (splash zone, upper, middle and lower shore). Key organisms at each level are highlighted in detail.
Factors affecting zonation in rocky shores communities are discussed. A list of fieldwork hints is included.
Title: Understanding Ecology Fieldwork 1. Rocky shore communities

Description: Aimed at GCSE and AS/A2, the Understanding Geography Fieldwork series of fold-out charts have been designed for independent student use in the field or in the classroom.

Statistics for Geographers, used successfully in draft form for many years by A-level geographers visiting FSC Field Centres, is intended to reduce students' reliance on their teachers when processing fieldwork data.

With a clear flow chart to guide choice of statistical tests when dealing with data (also useful at the planning stage!) and assuming no previous knowledge of statistics, full instructions and worked examples guide students through five of the most useful tests: Spearman's Rank, Mann-Whitney U, Chi-squared, Student's t and Pearson Product Moment. Tables of critical values for the most commonly used probability levels are also included.
Keywords: fold-out, fold out, FSC, field studies council
Title: Understanding Geography Fieldwork 1: Statistics for Geographers

Description: Central Business District is designed to support student-led field investigations in the CBD, and takes a structured route to enquiry approach. Although traditional concepts and techniques are outlined in full this chart suggests fresh issues to investigate, and how to go about investigating them.
Keywords: fold-out, fold out, FSC, field studies council
Title: Understanding Geography Fieldwork 2: The Central Business District

Description: This is a guide to carrying out geographical fieldwork on the topic of rivers. It contains concise background information on the stable channel balance and the features to look out for (both in the field and on a map) in the upper and middle courses, where fieldwork is most likely to be carried out.

A quick reference guide on the back cover contains a fieldwork reminder of the channel geometry features to look out for, plus a ready-made 'stone board' with radius of curvature measurement chart and Power's Shape Index guide.
Keywords: fold-out, fold out, FSC, field studies council
Title: Understanding geography fieldwork 3: The river environment

Description: Advice for sea users on how to deal with marine turtle encounters, including an identification guide to the five species of turtle seen in UK seas.
Title: United Kingdom Turtle Code

Description: This is a good time to look at urban lichens, as levels of sulphur dioxide, air pollution and acid rain have been falling rapidly. Many leafy lichens are growing in sites in central London where they may not have been present for 200 years.

The first urban lichens fold-out chart concentrates on the lichens found growing on trees and wood. The chart is illustrated with 49 colour photographs and includes an easy-to-use visual lichen identification key. See the second urban lichens chart.
Keywords: fold-out, fold out, FSC, field studies council
Title: Urban lichens 1 (on trees and wood)

Description: This is a good time to look at urban lichens, as levels of sulphur dioxide, air pollution and acid rain have been falling rapidly. Many leafy lichens are growing in sites in central London where they may not have been present for 200 years.

The second urban lichens fold-out chart concentrates on the lichens found growing on stone and soil. The chart is illustrated with 49 colour photographs and includes an easy-to-use visual lichen identification key.
Keywords: fold-out, fold out, FSC, field studies council
Title: Urban lichens 2 (on stone and soil)

Description: Collection and links to various keys to robberflies, including LUCID and conventional keys to the different tribes, families, genuses etc.
Title: Various keys to robberflies

Description: Vegetative identification keys (pdf files in English) for selected woody plant genera in Western European cultivation, composed by Jan De Langhe, dendrologist at Ghent University Botanical Garden in collaboration with Arboretum Wespelaar.
Title: Vegetative identification keys for selected woody plant genera in Western European cultivation

Description: RES Handbook Vol 6 Part 6. A general introduction is provided to the natural history and external morphology for the following families of the Vespoidea: Tiphiidae, Mutillidae, Sapygidae, Scoliidae and Vespidae including the subfamilies Eumeninae, Polistinae and Vespinae. A checklist is given for the 45 species that have been recorded from the British Isles. Keys to the families, genera and species, together with diagnostic illustrations, are provided. Notes are given on the preparation of specimens for identification. Species profiles include information on British and overseas distribution, habitats, adult activity period, nesting characteristics, prey, host records and flowers visited.
Keywords: Royal Entomological Society of London FSC entsoc
Title: The Vespoid Wasps

Description: A dichotomous key - in FRENCH - but very useable for adult and larvae of water beetles
Title: Water Beetle adults and larvae

Description: A video guide (short YouTube film) to the diagnostic features of Equisetum fluviatile (Water Horsetail) to aid in the identification of the species.
Title: Water horsetail - ID video

Description: A brilliant site for identifying British beetles. See in particular the "Species" and "ID Aids" links from the menus at the top of the page; elsewhere on the site there is guidance on field techniques and information on the group's recording activities.
Title: Watford Coleoptera Group

Description: These are draft guides to genera or species groups of weevils. It is being tested; if you have any ideas for improving the design or content, please send them to [[email protected]](../cdn-cgi/l/email-protection.html) or @MarkGurn on Twitter.
This is a guide to the genera or groups of weevils of Britain and Ireland.
Title: Weevil Guides

Description: Photo guide to the most commonly seen berries and fruiting trees and shrubs in hedgerows.
Title: Wild berry (& other fruit) spotter’s sheet

Description: Photo guide to the most commonly seen berries and fruiting trees and shrubs in hedgerows.
Title: Wild berry (& other fruit) spotter’s sheet

Description: App for identifying wild flowers of the UK.
Title: Wild Flower Id - The British Identification Guide to Wild Flowers

Description: Details of important corrections to the Wild Flower Key are set out in this PDF. These were omitted by the publisher in order to meet the deadline for publication.
Title: Wild Flower Key Corrigenda

Description: Photo guide to the most commonly seen wildflowers in woodland.
Title: Wild Plants of the Woods

Description: Photo guide to the most commonly seen wildflowers in August.
Title: Wildflowers to look for in August

Description: Photo guide to the most commonly seen wildflowers in September.
Title: Wildflowers to look for in September

Description: A 12 page laminated fold out guide covering the identification of 28 wader species known to occur in Britain and Ireland on a regular basis - perfect for taking into the field. The guide includes a simple identification key, wader silhouettes and stunning artwork by Mike Langman. It is part of an integrated suite of wader resources which also includes Identikit, a multi-access digital identification key, and Quizlet on-line flash card learning resource.
Title: WildID Waders of Britain and Ireland

Description: Identifying trees in winter without their familiar leaves can apear a daunting challenge, but a closer look will reveal a multitude of slowly swelling buds. A quick glance at the bud summary photos in this guide instantly reveals their sheer diversity. Generally they are extremely varied, and often easy to learn and remember. When you consider the difference between types of bark, size of tree and habitat, identification starts to become much easier than it seemed at first. This AIDGAP guide covers 36 of the common broad-leaved deciduous species, or groups of species, that are most likely to be found in the UK, as well as a few rarer trees.
Title: Winter trees: a photographic guide to common trees and shrubs

Description: A guide to spider webs commonly found in winter, and how they can help us find out which family or genus of spiders made them.
Title: Winter Webs

Description: Looking to identify the minibeasts of soil and leaf litter? Using a simple yes-and-no format to guide users through the trail, this fully illustrated fold-out chart has been used by generations of visitors to FSC Field Centres. This fold-out chart is designed to enable children (from age 7 upwards) and beginners to identify the invertebrates commonly found in woodland soils and leaf litter. The Fact File gives further information about the invertebrates and introduces food chains and webs.
Title: Woodland name trail (mini beasts)

Description: Colour illustrations of 41 species of common woodland plant are included in this 8-page laminated fold-out chart. Although the images are arranged by flower colour, a full identification key based on leaf characteristics is also included, so that plants can be identified when not in flower.
Title: Woodland plants

Description: 4 species of waterlice and 40 species of woodlice occur outdoors in Britain and Ireland. A further 12 introduced 'alien' species occur in artificial climates such as glasshouses. This new atlas presents the results of the Non-marine Isopod Recording Scheme to the end of 2007. The scheme has received 69,633 records for waterlice and 85,950 records for woodlice. This atlas represents a comprehensive synthesis of the information available on Isopods within Britain and Ireland. The results are presented as distribution maps embedded within species accounts which provide details of identification and particularly key features for separating similar (easily confused) species. Additional guidance is provided on collecting and recording these animals, plus detailed accounts of the biology and conservation of Isopods.
Keywords: BRC Biological Records Centre FSC Field Studies Council CEH
Title: Woodlice and Waterlice (Isopoda: Oniscidea & Asellota) in Britain and Ireland

Description: Woodlice are widespread and common animals. This fold-out chart provides a simple woodlouse identification trail to the species that are most likely to be encountered in gardens or in and around buildings.
Title: The woodlouse name trail

Description: This primarily a fully searchable online database covering spider taxonomy, but it has a longer history of predecessors which started with Pierre Bonnet (University of Toulouse, France) and Carl Friedrich Roewer (Bremen, Germany). However, if you sign up for a free login, you can have access, via the Bibliography, to a huge number of ID resources for personal use.
Title: World Spider Catalog

Description: A citizen science project dedicated to sharing wildlife sounds.
Keywords: Bioacoustic Soundscape Sound Call Birdsong Vocalisation Acoustic Docker
Title: Xeno-Canto
